instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Clean board, 3 ports make the usb meter restart every 5-6 seconds one port stays on, as far as I have read and seen videos there is no clear way to determine if a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is bad or not, in this particular case I would guess that those 3 ports are the ones with bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> since they are all getting 3.3v on pins 53 and 62 and only one has not restarting issues.

Now my question here is are there any other tricks to determine if a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is bad, I know that if one of them is bad in this case there are 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> on this board then the board will not start, this makes it difficult to repair this boars, also I have had issues in the past with bad "new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>" chips, so this is even worse for fixing and troubleshooting.

Thanks for input.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: For now what I do to test the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is to test them on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that I have here with a dead CPU but all else works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: If the amp meter loops when you plug it in, that means that the corresponding <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip should be working fine actually. The issue should be on the one port that does not loop and just stays on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message: I have some CD3215B03 chips, seems like those only work on some boards, for example on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> they don't work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
threads.message:
Compare diode mode readings on all LDO outputs of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Or change directly the chip which doesn't pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> troubleshotting <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
